data.title: List of Prisoners of Le Train Fantôme (Phantom Train)
data.meta_description: The following is a list of approximately 977 political prisoners on the Phantom Train (Nazi Ghost Train) with dates of birth for a large proportion of them.  (To view the list of Allied airmen who were on the train, click here.)  At the end of the list is information on the sources used and caveats…
data.text:
The following is a list of approximately 977 political prisoners on the Phantom Train (Nazi Ghost Train) with dates of birth for a large proportion of them. (To view the list of Allied airmen who were on the train, click here.) At the end of the list is information on the sources used and caveats as to the use of the list. The list includes titles for some of the prisoners. From members of the nobility, there were two counts and two barons. Religious titles show that there were three abbots, one vicar, four curates, and one sister. Military ranks include one general, two colonels, three commandants, two captains, and one lieutenant. For those for whom there are birth dates, the range of ages was 75 (Omer Joseph Labis, born in 1869) to 15 (Marcel Lepoivre, born in 1929).

ABEELE von DE JONGH (She appears on the list of members of the Smit-van der Heijden Line from Poppel.)

The above names of of approximately 977 civilian political prisoners on the Phantom Train was compiled from two sources:

(1) The Liste des Membres de l’Amicale Rescapés du dernier convoi — 3 September 1944 (List of Members of the Society of Survivors of the Last Convoy–3 September 1944) which I obtained from the Jewish Museum of Deportation and Resistance in Mechelen, Belgium.

(2) A list of persons who were arrested by German police but were liberated on 3 September 1944 at “la gare de la Petite Ile” (the Petite Ile railway station) whose possessions had been placed by the Belgian Red Cross with the bank Nagelmackers Fils &Cie. The list was obtained from the Section “Archives and Documentation,” Directorate-General “War Victims” of the Federal Public Service, Social Security, of the Belgian government in Brussels.

Caveats: The list of Members of the Society of Survivors was handwritten, which presented some problems in correctly interpreting spelling and birth dates. For most prisoners there is a birth date but some numbers were difficult, if not impossible, to read and I inserted question marks as needed. Sometimes names as well were hard to read because of light handwriting and the way the list was photocopied. Maiden names for women prisoners, when given, sometimes tended to run off the right edge of the photocopy. Some notations on the original, which, for the most part, I did not copy, had to do with where the person moved to. That plus the occasional entry “1949,” suggests the list was being used to keep track of members of the Society of Survivors on or after 1949.

The Nagelmackers Bank list was carefully typed. As a consequence, I was able to correct many, but not all, of the problems in the Society of Survivors list. Even in the Nagelmackers Bank list there were some type-overs which were difficult to read.

Some names were lined out on the Society of Survivors list but that appears to have had to do with their membership in the Society, not with whether they were truly prisoners.

To make it possible for the user of this list to know the source(s) of each name, I used the following system:

If the name appeared only on the Society of Survivors list, there is no notation.

If the name appeared on only the Nagelmackers Bank list, “Ng” appears at the end of the person’s listing.

If the name appeared on both lists, “Bh” appears at the end of the listing.

There may be some double entries when I could not be positive that two listings, one from each list, were not the same person. Different given names used on the two lists probably account for some duplication.

When searching for a name, keep in mind how Microsoft Word’s alphabetical sorting feature works. Names that start with a separate DE, DEN, LE, or VAN will be listed in separate groups. For a DE name, for example, look under not only the DE names but also under names where DE is combined with the rest of the name. For example, DE BEER, Emile appears in the DE group while DEBEER appears farther down the list in the rest of the D’s. For the same reason, the name T’JOEN appears at the beginning of the T’s, D’HONIT and D’OULTREMONT at the beginning of the D’s, and L’HOIR at the beginning of the L’s.

Instead of the French word née, I used bn for born. I used diacritical marks, e.g., ç, in many names but may have missed some of them.

When what appeared to be the same person’s name appeared on both lists but with slight variations in spelling or dates, I used parentheses to show both forms.

I would welcome any additions and corrections to the list. I plan a supplemental list that will include people who were on the train but whose names don’t appear in either of the two lists used above.
